330 ml bottle, pours black with a small foamy head, lively carbonation, aroma of chocolate malts, hints of caramel and a coffee, balanced really well with the juicy citrus hops which tingle on the tongue until giving way to a short bitter finish. Really good Black IPA.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2014 Aroma: grassy, citrusy hops, fresh, maybe some orange. Appearance: black, hardly any head. Taste: light sweet. Palate: light to medium bitters coming up, medium carbonation. Overall: fantastic IPA, one of the best balanced aromas. Pint at Dukes Brew& Que, 2nd tasting bottle at the London Drinker Beer & Cider Festival.

Bottle from Craft Beer Co. Pours black with a medium, very dense and firm lightly tanned head. Unbelievable lacing. The thick as buggery head stays on! Nose is heavy cocoa and light citric hoppage focusing on orange. Sweet and inviting. Very creamy stuff. Heavy espresso without being too bitter. Bitterness gradually takes over from heavy citric fruits which follow the coffee tones. Its kind of like a really good heavy dosed iced coffee. Great stuff. Drinks very well. Alcohol is light warmth on the finish which works just fine. Very good beer

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2015 Bottle and can from Rehills, Newcastle. A very dark brown-black beer with ruby red highlights and a large foamy head. It has chocolate, red fruity and sarsaparilla flavours, spicy citrus and pine with a slight nutty, roasted finish. Excellent!

Bottle at home sourced at sourced market. Opaque dark brown caramel colour persisted big bubble light tan head. Aroma is a huge melting pot of resinous pine citrus and roasted barley. Bold. Flavour is malt forward,  bitter coffee, slight choc, ash. Then the citrus lemon berry kicks in. Full body for a black IPA. Medium carbonation. Big bold but balanced. Really nice.

Bottle. Pours a dark black-brown, thin off-white head. Aroma: bold resinous hop notes (pine needles, grapefruit juice) with a good whack of roasted malts (drinking chocolate, filter coffee). Taste: hops, sticky dark fruits, cocoa powder, a touch of ash. Medium bodied, active carbonation. Super fresh & well executed. Brilliant!

Bottle. Very dark brown with a big tan head. Citrus, pine, coffee, dried fruit in the aroma. The contrasting flavours that make this a BIPA are having some sort of lovely orgy. Sweet yet, bitter. Aggressive hops with laidback dark malts. Citrus, pine, chocolate, burnt caramel, dates and some blackberry.  Nice medium body, with a resinous texture and soft carbonation. Sex.

Bottled (From AbM). Deep brown, close to black, colour with a mediumsized creamy beigeish brown head, that leaves some lace. Aroma is chocolate, roasted malts, some fruity and floral notes along with mild herbal notes as well. Flavour is ashy, chocolaty, mild toffee and some slight toasted notes along with quite mellow fruity and floral notes, but a big hoppy bitter kick in the finish. Well balanced, and pretty much this is the kind of black IPA I like.
bottle at home ... deep brown black ... thin tan head ... soft  roast ... big soft hop ... juicy ... dark malts ... ligth juicy malt ... soft roast ... light pine .. soft otffe roast
Bottle. Dark brown with tan head. Massive hop aroma, sharp ciyrus grapefruit and passion fruit aroma. Similar taste, lots of grapefruit with a little coffee and chocolate. Quite bitter. Delicious.
Bottle at Craig?s house. Very dark and very cloudy. Very small head. Doesn?t seem too gassy.

Bottle.  Thin slightly off-white head, jet black but with ruby highlights around the body.  Grapefruit, soapy, and earthy hops that are aggressive but somehow still a bit balanced, with coffee and roast aromas.  Great balance for a hop-driven Black IPA that I feel finally does what I want this style to be in terms of hops, some roast, but dry as shit and a clean hoppy finish.  Lighter to medium body with bubbly carbonation.  Fun brew!

330ml bottle. Nearly total blackness with a light brown head. The aroma is really excellent, with bucketloads of American hops conjuring up citrus, passion fruit and black grapes. It plays well against notes of cola and roasted malt that help to balance things out. Oily and viscous mouthfeel with a powerful bitter finish. Really impressive stuff all round.

(Bottle, Dukes Brew & Cue, Haggerston, London, 25 Apr 2013) Black colour with frothy, beige head. Malty, roasted nose with notes of coffee, chocolate, liquorice, resin and pine needles. Malty, roasted taste with liquorice, black coffee, dark chocolate and generous amounts of resinous, piney hops. More than medium body, quite dry. Impressive black IPA with lots of coffee, chocolate and hops. Excellent beer.

Bottle. Black ale with medium head that reduces to a residual head with good lacing. Aroma of hops and hops. Taste is a little coffee and quite a bit of hops, grapefruit and roasted malts. A little carbonation and oil on the palate. Good stuff.
user_location: West Bromwich (Yorkshire Expat), West Midlands, ENGLAND

text: Bottle 330ml. @ home.[ Trade by madmitch76 ]. Unclear dark dark blak brown colour with a large to huge, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly to fully lasting, light beige head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, chocolate, moderate to heavy hoppy, grass, pine, grapefruit, dusty hops - hop cones. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, soapy, citrus bitter, hoppy bitter, dark malt, dry grass. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20130325]

33cl bottle. Pitch black with tanned head. The head is medium big. Nose : strong roasted aromas of malt. Coffee with milk, black chocolate. Pine and pomelo peel. Sip : well carbonated with medium thick body. Very sweet, almost like honey. Roasted aromas, black chocolate aftertaste. The beer is well hopped with pine and citrus aromas. After couple of sips I get some earthy notes and feeling on my tongue. Very good balance. A bit to cloying sweet though.

Appearance: Dark and subtle red color with a creamy beige head that leaves a lovely lacing.Aroma: Dark malt, rich hoppy and fruity.Palate: Medium pluss body. Slightly sweet and a rich bitterness. Average carbonation. Oily texture.Taste: A round fine dark malty base. Grape hoppy, fruity and coffee. Overall impression: Lovely stuff! Personal stats: Bottle from a trade with tomman.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2013 A rather complex flavour, first of all it tastes like ipa, Hoppy, floral, then there is an intense minerality, a sucker punch of sweet, bitter, sour fading to an aftertaste of bitterness, stout-like coffee flavour. Interesting,  the alcohol really comes through.

(33 cl bottle from Dukes Brew and Que; No BBD) Pours black with medium, tan head. Good retention and lace. Aroma is fresh herbal, grassy and sprucy hops with no detectable malt aroma. Oily texture, full body, medium carbonation and a bitter finish. Flavour reveaks a very smooth and well composed hoppy drinking experience with sufficient malt to put a dampener on the bitterness but without the roasted qualities that sometimes accompany dark beers. Very well done.

330ml bottle. Couldnt get excited about this, the aroma and flavour reminded me of CocaCola and it had about the same complexity. Reasonably well made thoughand could be far more complex if there was a decent proportion of hops in the copper rather than mainly post fermentation addition.
Bottle at BrewDog Pub, Camden Town, London. Black beer with a medium offwhite/beige head. Hoppy, fruity and cassis aroma. Similar flavour.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2016 330ml bottle from Ales by Mail
Born 10/12/12, death 10.3.13 - Pours pitch black with a massive sticky and foamy light brown head. Aroma of lovely fresh fruity hops, citrusy notes, grass, hints of roasty chocolate and coffee. Taste is sweetish, massively fruity and hoppy with notes of zesty citrus, lemon, pine, grass and some roastiness. Fruity and hoppy finish with tangy bitterness, roastiness and hints of coffee. Fresh, tasty and hoppy black IPA. Excellent stuff! 8-4-9-4-16. 
Re-rated after multiple cans over the years. Probably the best black IPA thats easily available. Tasty, excellent balance and huge roasty, lingering bitter finish. This one has grown into one of my favorites. Super tasty.
roasty, citrus, smoke, black, tan foam,  medium sweetness,full body, thick feel, soft carbonation, bitter, long bitter finish, Excellent example of a BIPA. Bold flavours yet balanced - first class.

Sharp citrus aromas mostly lime and grapefruit but with a hint or orange.  Behind lurks a pine like hint.  Pours nearly jet black with a creamy long lasting head.  In the flavour a mix of bitterness and roast keeps the interest going
Excellent beer combining the smooth, malty coffee taste of a stout and the sharp hops of an IPA. Just the right balance. Not at all overpowering so you can enjoy a few.
Bottle from Cotteridge Wines. Absolutely first class beer - an outstanding Black IPA. Super smooth. Beautifully sweet. Chocolate malt bounds and gambols around the gorgeous fruit. First class.

330ml bottle at 7.2%.  Pours black with a large head.  Aroma is passion fruit, blackcurrant and a little dry coffee underneath.  Taste is passion fruit throughout with a bitter finish.  Some chocolate also.

Pours darkest mahogany brown with fluffy mocha head. Pine and oranges big on the nose. Medium mouth feel and scrubbing carbonation meet a high residual sweetness terrys chocolate orange. On warming more pithy citrus emerges but no hint of the dark malt. Up there with the best!

Bottle. Very dark brown - almost black, average to large and mostly lasting light brown head. Moderate to full, malty and sweetish aroma, faint caramel, some roasted malt and some tropical fruitiness, lots of grapefruit - piney hoppyness. Body is medium to full, malty and lightly sweetish flavor, faint caramel, some roasted malt and some tropical fruitiness, grapefruit - piney hoppyness. Finish is average to long, malty and dryish, some roasted malt and some tropical fruitiness, lots of piney hoppyness. Really well done dryish BIPA. Not too much roasted malt - finish has some fruitiness. Bitterness is not sharp - soapy.

Bottle from Cotteridge Wines, pours dark black, big off white head, wow this is a real style definer perfectly balanced hops and malts, none of this stout dressed up as a trendy BIPA nonsense, oh yes I like this will be having again.

Bottle from Mr Lawrence, SE London - Pours dark brown/virtually black with a massive beige head which reduces slightly but never dissipates fully and leaves glorious lacing aplenty clinging to the glass. Rich roasted, toffee, cocoa  chocolate malts combines with nuances of citrus hops, grapefruit, pine and liquorice notes as well. Lovely mouthfeel, smooth texture, amazing balance of sweet/bitterness on the palate. Seriously impressive stuff this. Beautiful.

33cl bottle from The Bottle Shop, Canterbury.  Black beer with a lasting beige head.  Good hoppy aroma with a hint of roast.  Good mouthfeel.  I dont normally like black IPAs but this one is really good.  REally good in mouth too.  Its a fine big beer.  Lovely.  Good choc good biting hops on finish.

Bottle. Thin head and dark brown to black colour. Smell of hops and notes of citrus, grass and raisins. Well balanced taste as far as the hops and the malts. Medium to heavy bitterness. Its really refreshing and lingers. Medium body.

33cl bottle. Pours dark brown with a nice light brown head. Aroma is very complex: a lot of citrus and grapefruit, also some toffee, pine and melon. Well balanced between the citrus/pine finish and the darker roasted elements. Amazing.

Bottle from Cotteridge Wines, Birmingham.  Poured a dark murky mahogany with a thin tan head and broken lace.  The aroma is hoppy and spicy.  The flavour is rich, bitter, spicy and with lots of liqourice.   The palate is dry and has peppery spice.  Its just 7.4% but it tastes stronger than that. A super beer from Beavertown.

Bottle at Brewdog Camden, London. Black beer with a nice beige head. Hoppy fruity aroma, creamy, caramel, citrus, pine needles, toffee notes, roasted, lemongrass, pineapples, black currants, raisins, floral notes. Hoppy floral flavor, caramel, creamy notes, floral, metal, perfume notes, pine needles, citrus, peach, some toffee notes, some pineapples.
Totally delicious. Down like a dream. Smooth, soft fruits, very few coins, any metal is like liquid mercury. Quality balanced brewing. I wanna live in beavertown, sounds quite hot.
I rather like Leadbelly and this is rather special as well. I was sold on the image and this beer backs it up. Dark and bitter, just how I like it. Long live Beavertown.

Bottle @ The Union Tavern. The pours deep brown with a medium off-white head. The nose is sharp woodland grass, rich roasted chocolate malt. The taste is peppery hop, light pineapple sweetness. Dried, salty driftwood. Loads of ashy roasted malts in the finish. Bitter chocolate. Acerbic, bold flavors. Rich, medium body. Active carbonation. Overall, an out-sized black IPA. Very well played, Beavertown.

Bottle from beermerchants.com. A dark brown/black coloured pour with a medium off white head on top. Hoppy, citrus fruit aroma. Tastes hoppy, citrus fruit, grapefruit, hint of chocolate, slightly bitter. Rich,complex and tasty, reminded me a little of Kernel. Nice one from Beavertown who are the best of the new crop of Hackney brewers IMO..

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2013 18th November 2012Opaque black beer with a big pale tan head. Smooth palate, semi dry and with fine carbonation. Dry dark malt, creamy and with a whisper of roast. Bitter hops, touch of citrus but mostly just bitter. Finishes dry and bitter. Too dry and bitter. A head scratcher this one - everyone seems to love this except me. Must try another bottle. 2.331st January 2013Opaque black - brown beer, good pale tan head. Soft palate. Creamy dark malt. Mild piney hops. Trace of red berry fruits. Finishes smooth. Fairly simple stuff but this bottle hung together well whereas my first one was a mess,

Bottle at home (Beermerchants.com) 22/11/12.
Pours a light shade of black with a mahooosive frothy tan head. Thins after a few minutes but retains well. Good lacing follows.
Nose is absoultely spot on - hops, big shreds of pine, little toastyness, tropical fruits with grapefruit and mango at the fore.
Taste is bitter grapefruit, pine, juicy hops, a little spice, light chocolate notes.
Medium bodied, soft carbonation, bitter and sweetness in the finish.
Excellent Black IPA from this new (ish) London brewer
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Bottle at Euston Tap. Black, beige head. Citrus hops aroma, hints of roast. Solid bitterness. Nice one.

Bottle at home 27th October 2012. This is lovely, smooth and rich, pours to form a nice fluffy white head, aroma of berry and some cappachino, taste is initially sweet blackberry, quickly followed by a bitter cocoa finish and malt that lingers, great BIPA

UPDATED: AUG 5, 2015 Bottle at home in London. Pours rich brown with a huge, lasting beige foam head. Aroma holds a stupid amount of resinous pine, with some background roast. Medium sweet flavor fronted by that piney goodness, backed by rich and chocolatey malts, some dirt, a bit of grapefruit, some dry cocoa. Medium bodied with fine, smooth carbonation. Well and sticky resinous finish, lots of burnt grass and pine, moderate roast, sturdy chocolate malts, some baking cocoa, earth, a bit of dry cocoa. Alright, OK - wow. This is the real thing. I cant stop drinking this beer. I dont know who these Beavertown fellas think they are, but they need to give me a warning before they spring a beer like this on us. Outstanding. (11/9/2012, score: 4.3)Can at home in London - sourced recently from the brewery. Pours deep black-brown with a dense, creamy beige head. Great aroma. At first it seems like it will be rich with roasted malts, but then a really strong, dynamic hop profile begins to take hold, with lots of pine, ripening citrus, burnt herbs. Medium sweet flavor with smooth, almost creamy dark bread character, cut hard by well roasted malts, and beefed up with an outrageous onslaught of hop characteristics, predominantly oily and sticky pine, orange rind, grapefruit juice, mild bitter grass. Medium to full bodied, oily and lightly chewy, with fine to average carbonation. Finishes with exceptional depth and balance, just oozing with resinous hops, sturdy roast, baking cocoa, rindy citrus, gooey pine. Good lord, this stuff is truly outstanding. Even better than I remember. This is truly one of the best black IPAs in the world. Im bumping up my score to 4.6. (5 August 2015, score: 4.6)

Bottle at the Euston Tap. It pours opaque dark brown, with a medium light beige head. The nose is hopsack, roasted malt, ash, bitter chocolate and some citrus. The taste is roasted malt, charcoal, ash, liquorice, dark berry (particularly blackcurrant), light citrus, burnt toast and cocoa, with a charry finish. Medium body and moderate carbonation. Balance is spot on. Rich, flavoursome and damn delicious.

Pours a deliciously thick black with an amazing hop burst rising out of the glass. Packed with the pungent fruit of citra hops the beers backbone holds it up well. Exquisitely balanced, with a moderate roast character letting the hops do the bittering. There is sweetness in there but exactly the right amount. This is a hell of a beer.
